metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: XML Elements vs. Attributes
In XML, there are no rules about when to use attributes, and when to use child elements.
content.html: In XML, there are no rules about when to use attributes, and when to use child elements.

content.text: Use of Elements vs. Attributes
Data can be stored in child elements or in attributes.
content.html: Data can be stored in child elements or in attributes.

content.text: Take a look at these examples:

content.code_html:
<person sex="female">
  <firstname>Anna</firstname>
  <lastname>Smith</lastname>
</person>

<person>
  <sex>female</sex>
  <firstname>Anna</firstname>
  <lastname>Smith</lastname>
</person>

content.text: In the first example sex is an attribute. In the last, sex is a child element. Both examples provide the same information.
content.html: In the first example sex is an attribute. In the last, sex is a child element. Both examples provide the same information.

content.text: There are no rules about when to use attributes, and when to use child elements. My experience is that attributes are handy in HTML, but in XML you should try to avoid them. Use child elements if the information feels like data.
content.html: There are no rules about when to use attributes, and when to use child elements. My experience is that attributes are handy in HTML, but in XML you should try to avoid them. Use child elements if the information feels like data.

content.text: My Favorite Way
I like to store data in child elements.
content.html: I like to store data in child elements.

content.text: The following three XML documents contain exactly the same information:
content.html: The following three XML documents contain exactly the same information:

content.text: A date attribute is used in the first example:
content.html: A date attribute is used in the first example:

content.code_html:
<note date="12/11/2002">
  <to>Tove</to>
  <from>Jani</from>
  <heading>Reminder</heading>
  <body>Don't forget me this weekend!</body>
</note>

content.text: A date element is used in the second example:
content.html: A date element is used in the second example:

content.code_html:
<note>
  <date>12/11/2002</date>
  <to>Tove</to>
  <from>Jani</from>
  <heading>Reminder</heading>
  <body>Don't forget me this weekend!</body>
</note>

content.text: An expanded date element is used in the third: (THIS IS MY FAVORITE):
content.html: An expanded date element is used in the third: (THIS IS MY FAVORITE):

content.code_html:
<note>
  <date>
    <day>12</day>
    <month>11</month>
    <year>2002</year>
  </date>
  <to>Tove</to>
  <from>Jani</from>
  <heading>Reminder</heading>
  <body>Don't forget me this weekend!</body>
</note>

content.text: Avoid using attributes?
Should you avoid using attributes?
Some of the problems with attributes are:
content.html: Some of the problems with attributes are:

content.text: If you use attributes as containers for data, you end up with documents that are difficult to read and maintain. Try to use elements to describe data. Use attributes only to provide information that is not relevant to the data.
content.html: If you use attributes as containers for data, you end up with documents that are difficult to read and maintain. Try to use elements to describe data. Use attributes only to provide information that is not relevant to the data.

content.text: Don't end up like this (this is not how XML should be used):
content.html: Don't end up like this (this is not how XML should be used):

syntaxHighlighting.text:
<note day="12" month="11" year="2002"
to="Tove" from="Jani" heading="Reminder"
body="Don't forget me this weekend!">

day="12" month="11" year="2002"
to="Tove" from="Jani" heading="Reminder"
body="Don't forget me this weekend!"

content.code:
<note day="12" month="11" year="2002"
to="Tove" from="Jani" heading="Reminder"
body="Don't forget me this weekend!">

</note>

syntax_highlighting.text:
<note day="12" month="11" year="2002"
to="Tove" from="Jani" heading="Reminder"
body="Don't forget me this weekend!">

day="12" month="11" year="2002"
to="Tove" from="Jani" heading="Reminder"
body="Don't forget me this weekend!"

content.code_html:
<note day="12" month="11" year="2002"
to="Tove" from="Jani" heading="Reminder"
body="Don't forget me this weekend!">
</note>

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
<note day="12" month="11" year="2002"
to="Tove" from="Jani" heading="Reminder"
body="Don't forget me this weekend!">

day="12" month="11" year="2002"
to="Tove" from="Jani" heading="Reminder"
body="Don't forget me this weekend!"

content.text: An Exception to my Attribute Rule
Rules always have exceptions.
My rule about attributes has one exception:
content.html: My rule about attributes has one exception:

content.text: Sometimes I assign ID references to elements. These ID references can be used to access XML elements in much the same way as the NAME or ID attributes in HTML. This example demonstrates this:
content.html: Sometimes I assign ID references to elements. These ID references can be used to access XML elements in much the same way as the NAME or ID attributes in HTML. This example demonstrates this:

content.code:
<messages>

<note id="p501">


<to>Tove</to>


<from>Jani</from>


<heading>Reminder</heading>


<body>Don't forget me this weekend!</body>

</note>


<note id="p502">


<to>Jani</to>


<from>Tove</from>


<heading>Re: Reminder</heading>


<body>I will not!</body>

</note>

</messages>
content.code_html:
<messages>
<note id="p501">
  <to>Tove</to>
  <from>Jani</from>
  <heading>Reminder</heading>
  <body>Don't forget me this weekend!</body>
</note>

<note id="p502">
  <to>Jani</to>
  <from>Tove</from>
  <heading>Re: Reminder</heading>
  <body>I will not!</body>
</note>
</messages>

content.text: The ID in these examples is just a counter, or a unique identifier, to identify the different notes in the XML file, and not a part of the note data.
content.html: The ID in these examples is just a counter, or a unique identifier, to identify the different notes in the XML file, and not a part of the note data.

content.text: What I am trying to say here is that metadata (data about data) should be stored as attributes, and that data itself should be stored as elements.
content.html: What I am trying to say here is that metadata (data about data) should be stored as attributes, and that data itself should be stored as elements.
